metadata.name: Hourly CFE Optimizer Literature Review
metadata.description: Consolidated literature review for the Hourly Clean Energy Cost Optimizer project. Contains all academic references, data sources, and key findings from published research that inform the optimizer methodology, cost assumptions, and analytical framework.
metadata.purpose: Referenceable object to prevent redundant web sweeps of existing literature in future sessions

key_findings_from_literature.hourly_vs_annual: Xu et al. (2024) show hourly matching produces 2-3x higher costs than annual matching but 5-10x more real emission reductions
key_findings_from_literature.firm_clean_power: Jenkins et al. (2018) establish that reaching >80% clean requires dispatchable firm clean power; intermittent renewables alone cannot economically close the gap
key_findings_from_literature.last_mile_costs: Denholm et al. (2022) document exponential cost escalation for final 5-10% of clean electricity targets
key_findings_from_literature.ldes_potential: Dowling et al. (2020) model 20-40% cost reduction from LDES at high renewable penetration
key_findings_from_literature.voluntary_procurement: Xu et al. (2024, Joule) show combined RPS + voluntary C&I demand on regional supply curves produces non-linear cost escalation
key_findings_from_literature.rec_economics: Gillenwater (2008) establishes that only when combined demand creates real scarcity does voluntary procurement drive new investment
key_findings_from_literature.cfe_premium: Riepin & Brown (2024) find 98% CFE = 54% cost premium, 100% requires clean firm + LDES
key_findings_from_literature.overbuild_references: Budischak et al.: 280% overbuild for 100% targets; WattTime: 400% overbuild reference
